learning_outcomes.description: Describe physiological mechanisms that support the functions of the major organ systems in the human body.
Explain how nervous and endocrine signals are essential to whole-body physiological responses.
Identify normal physiological responses and distinguish them from abnormal responses associated with human disease.
Investigate how the human body responds to challenges and attempts to maintain homeostasis.
Perform key observational and experimental techniques in human physiology, including acquisition and analysis of quantitative data.
Design and implement a physiological experiment, and critically analyse and communicate its findings, with supporting evidence from the scientific literature.
Reflect on your learning and skill development in scientific methods and communication
Work and learn collaboratively, capitalising on the diverse abilities, backgrounds and perspectives within the group

assessments.assessment_title: Laboratory Assessment Series: Hypothesis, outline & bibliography (group work)
assessments.task_description:
Draft hypothesis, experiment outline & annotated bibliography completed as a group during class. Further assessment details will be provided on Blackboard during the semester.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This task will be submitted to your tutor at the end of the 2nd lab class for your practical group.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Laboratory Assessment Series: Experiment Design Proposal (group work)
assessments.task_description:
Experiment Proposal Presentation slides & talk (group work): Includes the slides presented and a 5 minute oral talk on the hypothesis & aims, design, methods and expected outcomes of your group's proposed experiment. Further assessment details will be provided on Blackboard during the semester.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: Late submission is not available for this in-class assessment item.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Upon submission of the Lab Report, you should check in the Turnitin Assignment Inbox page that your report was submitted successfully. Further assessment details will be provided on Blackboard during the semester.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your Assessment task, with the electronic coversheet available on the Schools website to Turnitin by the submission deadline. You may submit drafts to Turnitin up to the due date, but you will only be able to submit once on or after the due date. You should also keep an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit.

assessments.task_description:
This exam covers all lecture content and will be comprised of multiple choice, short answer, and various other question types.

The exam will be a closed book invigilated exam held on campus, undertaken via the Inspera eAssessment platform. Students will be required to bring a laptop to the exam that meets the device requirements for Inspera. It is important that you check before the exam that your laptop meets the device requirements for using the Inspera Assessment platform. If you do not own a suitable laptop, you can borrow one from the Library. The Library website Get familiar with Inspera provides the latest information for students about using Inspera. Further information about the exam will be provided on Blackboard.

Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture Modules

The lectures are divided into modules on the following physiological systems -

  • Autonomic Nervous System (2 lectures)
  • Cardiovascular System (6 lectures)
  • Respiratory System (5 lectures)
  • Renal System (3 lectures)
  • Gastrointestinal System (4 lectures)
  • Neuromotor System (5 lectures)
  • Muscle Fatigue (2 lectures)
  • Endocrine System (5 lectures)
  • Integrative physiology (1 lecture)


Three lectures are scheduled most weeks. All lectures will be delivered in person, and also recorded for later viewing.




Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture Modules The lectures are divided into modules on the following physiological systems - Autonomic Nervous System (2 lectures) Cardiovascular System (6 lectures) Respiratory System (5 lectures) Renal System (3 lectures) Gastrointestinal System (4 lectures) Neuromotor System (5 lectures) Muscle Fatigue (2 lectures) Endocrine System (5 lectures) Integrative physiology (1 lecture) Three lectures are scheduled most weeks. All lectures will be delivered in person, and also recorded for later viewing.

learning_activities.topic:
Practical 1. Blood Pressure and Flow

The first of the 'skill-building' laboratory classes, focusing on the maintenance of tissue perfusion through control of blood pressure, volume and flow


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Practical 1. Blood Pressure and Flow The first of the 'skill-building' laboratory classes, focusing on the maintenance of tissue perfusion through control of blood pressure, volume and flow

learning_activities.topic:
Practical 2. Oxygen and Energy Supply

The second of the 'skill-building' laboratory classes, focusing on meeting the demands of the tissues for nutrients and oxygen through the reponses of the respiratory system and in fuel metabolism


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L08
learning_activities.topic_description: Practical 2. Oxygen and Energy Supply The second of the 'skill-building' laboratory classes, focusing on meeting the demands of the tissues for nutrients and oxygen through the reponses of the respiratory system and in fuel metabolism

learning_activities.topic:
Practical 3. Presentation

This class will be the opportunity for each group to finalise and present the proposal for their experiment to the whole class, and for the class to select and refine the final design.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Practical 3. Presentation This class will be the opportunity for each group to finalise and present the proposal for their experiment to the whole class, and for the class to select and refine the final design.

learning_activities.topic:
Practical 4. Experiment Week 1

The first of two experimental sessions, where each group will perform the experiments and collect the data.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L08
learning_activities.topic_description: Practical 4. Experiment Week 1 The first of two experimental sessions, where each group will perform the experiments and collect the data.

The second of two experimental sessions, where each group will perform the experiments and collect the data.

learning_activities.topic_description: Practical 5. Experimental Week 2 The second of two experimental sessions, where each group will perform the experiments and collect the data.

learning_activities.topic:
Practical 6. Analysis

The final class will give you an opportunity to analyse the data and interpret the findings in preparation for your laboratory report.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L08
